prompt:
Use the graph to evaluate the limit.

Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 2^-} f(x)$.

options.explanation: Approaching $x=2$ from the left follows the left linear branch, which approaches $y=3$ at the open circle.
$4$ is the function value shown by the filled point at $x=2$, not the left-hand limit.
A one-sided limit can exist even if the two-sided limit fails; from the left the values approach a single number.
$2$ confuses the $x$-value being approached with the $y$-value of the limit.

explanation: As $x\to 2^-$, the graph follows the left branch. The $y$-values approach $3$ (the open circle at $(2,3)$). Therefore, $\lim_{x\to 2^-} f(x)=3$.

micro_explanations.B: Filled point is $f(2)$, not the left limit.

recommendation_reasons: Targets one-sided limit reading from a graph.
Reinforces open vs closed circle meaning.
notes: Prompt uses an image (graph). Common traps: using the filled point, ignoring one-sided notation.
title: C3Q1_LeftHandLimitAt2

prompt:
Use the graph to evaluate the limit.

Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 1} f(x)$.

options.explanation: $1$ matches the right-hand approach (and the filled point), but the left-hand approach is different.
$3$ matches the left-hand approach (open circle), but the right-hand approach is different.
Left-hand and right-hand limits are different ($3$ from the left and $1$ from the right), so the two-sided limit does not exist.
$2$ is not approached from either side; it results from averaging or guessing.

explanation: From the left, $f(x)$ approaches $3$ (open circle at $(1,3)$). From the right, $f(x)$ approaches $1$ (horizontal segment). Since $\lim_{x\to 1^-} f(x)\neq \lim_{x\to 1^+} f(x)$, $\lim_{x\to 1} f(x)$ does not exist.
recommendation_reasons: Tests DNE via mismatch of one-sided limits.
Builds discipline: two-sided requires both sides match.
notes: Prompt uses an image (graph). Emphasize comparing one-sided limits rather than using $f(1)$.
title: C3Q2_TwoSidedLimitJumpAt1

prompt:
Use the graph to evaluate the limit.

Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)$.

options.explanation: The branch shown for $x>0$ rises upward as $x\to 0^+$, not downward.
As $x\to 0^+$, the graph increases without bound, so the one-sided limit is $\infty$.
The $x$-axis is not being approached; the $y$-values grow large.
An infinite limit is a valid limit description; here the behavior is unbounded in a single direction.

explanation: Near $x=0$ on the right, the graph shoots upward without bound. Therefore, $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=\infty$.

micro_explanations.D: Infinite limit is a type of limit.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces interpreting vertical asymptote behavior.
Targets sign of infinity with one-sided approach.
notes: Prompt uses an image (graph). Common error: writing DNE instead of $\infty$ or choosing wrong sign.
title: C3Q3_InfiniteLimitAt0Plus

prompt:
Use the graph to evaluate the limit.

Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to -1} f(x)$.

options.explanation: A hole does not prevent a limit from existing; the surrounding values can still approach one number.
$-1$ is the $x$-value being approached, not the $y$-value of the limit.
Near $x=-1$, the graph lies on the horizontal line $y=1$ with a hole at $(-1,1)$, so the limit is $1$.
The graph is not approaching $y=0$ near $x=-1$.

explanation: Approaching $x=-1$ from either side, the graph stays at $y=1$. Even though there is a hole at $(-1,1)$, the approaching value is $1$, so $\lim_{x\to -1} f(x)=1$.
recommendation_reasons: Differentiates limit existence from function value.
Targets removable discontinuity interpretation.
notes: Prompt uses an image (graph). Common error: claiming DNE because of the hole.
title: C3Q4_RemovableDiscontinuityAtMinus1

prompt:
Use the graph to evaluate the limit.

Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)$.

options.explanation: At $x=0$, the graph begins at $y=0$, not $1$.
As $x\to 0^+$ along the curve, $y\to 0$.
A right-hand limit can exist even if there is no left side shown.
The curve does not blow up near $x=0$; it approaches $0$.

explanation: The graph is defined for $x\ge 0$ and approaches the point $(0,0)$ from the right. Therefore, $\lim_{x\to 0^+} f(x)=0$.
recommendation_reasons: Builds comfort with endpoint/right-hand limits.
Reinforces meaning of $0^+$.
notes: Prompt uses an image (graph). Common error: forcing a two-sided limit when only right side is relevant.
title: C3Q5_RightHandLimitAt0

prompt:
A function $f$ is defined near $x=3$. Use the table to estimate $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 3} f(x)$.

$$
\begin{array}{c|cccccc}
x & 2.9 & 2.99 & 2.999 & 3.001 & 3.01 & 3.1\\ \hline
f(x) & 5.7 & 5.97 & 5.997 & 6.003 & 6.03 & 6.3
\end{array}
$$

options.explanation: This is just one value from the left side; the limit should reflect values from both sides approaching the same number.
Values approach $6$ from both sides: $5.997$ (left) and $6.003$ (right) get closer to $6$ as $x$ nears $3$.
This is just one value from the right side; it is not the best estimate of the limiting value.
Both sides trend toward the same value, so the limit exists.

explanation: As $x$ approaches $3$ from the left, $f(x)$ moves from $5.97$ to $5.997$. From the right, it moves from $6.03$ to $6.003$. These values cluster around $6$, so $\lim_{x\to 3} f(x)\approx 6$.
recommendation_reasons: Trains reading two-sided behavior from tables.
Counters the habit of picking one nearby entry.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX.
title: C4Q1_TableLimitApproaches6

prompt:
Use the table to determine $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$.

$$
\begin{array}{c|cccccc}
x & 1.9 & 1.99 & 1.999 & 2.001 & 2.01 & 2.1\\ \hline
f(x) & -1.1 & -1.01 & -1.001 & 3.001 & 3.01 & 3.1
\end{array}
$$

options.explanation: This is an average of the one-sided behaviors, but limits are not found by averaging.
This matches the left-hand trend, but the right-hand trend approaches a different value.
This matches the right-hand trend, but the left-hand trend approaches a different value.
Left-hand values approach $-1$ while right-hand values approach $3$, so the two-sided limit does not exist.

explanation: From the left of $2$, $f(x)$ approaches $-1$ (e.g., $-1.001$). From the right of $2$, $f(x)$ approaches $3$ (e.g., $3.001$). Since the one-sided limits are unequal, $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$ does not exist.
recommendation_reasons: Directly tests DNE using left vs right trends in a table.
Targets the common averaging mistake.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX.
title: C4Q2_TableTwoSidedLimitDNE

prompt:
Use the table to evaluate the limit.

$$
\begin{array}{c|cccccc}
x & -0.1 & -0.01 & -0.001 & 0.001 & 0.01 & 0.1\\ \hline
f(x) & 10 & 100 & 1000 & 1000 & 100 & 10
\end{array}
$$

Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$.

options.explanation: The values grow larger as $x$ gets closer to $0$, not smaller.
All listed function values are positive and increasing in magnitude near $0$, so the trend is not toward $-\infty$.
As $x$ approaches $0$ from both sides, $f(x)$ increases without bound, indicating an infinite limit of $\infty$.
Here the function grows without bound in the same direction on both sides, so describing the limit as $\infty$ is appropriate.

explanation: When $x$ is closer to $0$ (e.g., $\pm 0.001$), $f(x)$ is much larger (1000) than when $x$ is farther (e.g., $\pm 0.1$ gives 10). The values increase without bound as $x\to 0$, so $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)=\infty$.

micro_explanations.D: Infinite limit is a valid description here.

recommendation_reasons: Reinforces recognizing infinite limits from numerical data.
Targets the DNE vs $\infty$ misconception.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX.
title: C4Q3_TableInfiniteLimit

prompt:
A function $f$ is defined near $x=2$. Use the table to estimate
$$\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 2}\frac{f(x)-f(2)}{x-2}.$$

$$
\begin{array}{c|cccccc}
x & 1.9 & 1.99 & 1.999 & 2.001 & 2.01 & 2.1\\ \hline
f(x) & 4.61 & 4.9601 & 4.996001 & 5.004001 & 5.0401 & 5.41
\end{array}
$$

Assume $f(2)=5$.

options.explanation: The quotient is not near $0$; the changes in $f(x)$ relative to changes in $x$ suggest a slope near $4$.
$5$ is $f(2)$, but the expression is about the rate of change (slope), not the function value.
Left and right quotients both approach about $4$, indicating the limit exists.

explanation: Compute the difference quotient near $2$. From the right: $(5.004001-5)/0.001\approx 4.001$. From the left: $(4.996001-5)/(-0.001)\approx 3.999$. Both sides approach $4$, so the limit is approximately $4$.
recommendation_reasons: Connects tabular estimation with the key limit form for instantaneous rate of change.
Trains correct setup using $f(2)$ and $(x-2)$.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX. This stays within Chapter 1.4 by estimating a limit from a table.
title: C4Q4_DifferenceQuotientFromTable

prompt:
Use the table to determine $\displaystyle \lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$.

$$
\begin{array}{c|cccccc}
x & -0.1 & -0.01 & -0.001 & 0.001 & 0.01 & 0.1\\ \hline
f(x) & 1 & -1 & 1 & -1 & 1 & -1
\end{array}
$$

options.explanation: Averaging the two values is not justified; the function values do not trend toward $0$.
Values near $0$ are sometimes $1$ and sometimes $-1$; there is no single value approached.
Values near $0$ are sometimes $-1$ and sometimes $1$; there is no single value approached.
The function values oscillate between $1$ and $-1$ near $0$, so they do not approach a single number.

explanation: As $x$ gets closer to $0$, the outputs keep switching between $1$ and $-1$. Since the values do not settle on a single number, $\lim_{x\to 0} f(x)$ does not exist.

micro_explanations.A: Averaging is not a limit rule.

recommendation_reasons: Tests a high-frequency misconception: 'nearby values' can alternate and still fail to have a limit.
Builds recognition of oscillation as a DNE pattern.
notes: No image needed; table provided in KaTeX. Designed as a discrimination item (Level5).
title: C4Q5_TableOscillationDNE
